I dare say that this game isn't as fun as the original ExciteBike stand-up arcade game.  At least there you had control and things made sense.  Then there's the speed of this game.  It's mind-numbingly slow movements combined with the way the physics make no sense leaves me feeling a bit sick after just a few minutes of playing.

The graphics options...there are none.   I mean NONE.  Not even a screen size resolution option.  Not even a Full Screen option.  It starts (and stays) in 'windowed mode' at what looks like 1280x720.  The only way to get Full Screen is to Maximize the game window in the Task Manager.    The quality of the graphics is absolutely unacceptable in this day and age.   It's probably one of the worst looking and worst playing motocross game i've ever played.

Worth $24.00?  Absolutely not!  Real wotrh (using other Steam games and prices as a guide) - $4.

Immediate dissappointment. I have 2 copies of this game for Xbox and I have it on PC. It's almost the same as MX vs ATV Alive but the physics are worse. A lot of the gear and music in the game is exactly the same as Alive, the graphics look just like Alive, but the bikes handle terribly. when you first start the game it takes a very long time to unlock upgrades, tires, gear etc. the bikes slide out very easily until you unlock tires that hook up better. In the air the bikes handle like tanks, it's very difficult to move the bikes in the air. The physics are what make this game so bad, the bikes dont carry hardly any forward momentum when you hit jumps, they get a lot of air and then it's like somebody turned the gravity on and they fall almost straight down. Using the clutch is a must is corners and if tap the clutch repeatedly you go faster in the straits for some reason. Also, if you put your settings on manual transmission, you can keep you're bike in 5th gear all the way around the track and clutch boost like no other, it's incredibly unrealistic. As much as I dislike this game, I did enjoy racing pit bikes! The pit bikes are the only reason I even own the game on PC, they're very agressive, and they somehow clear all the jumps that you can clear on a 250. So if you're looking for a game that you'll play for a long time and captures that real racing feeling, this game isn't the one, but if you're looking for something that might be fun for a week, it might suit you.

**Update Oct 30, 2015**

Game is a little bit better. More features and tweaks have been added to the game that've made it a little more playable. Still not that great of a game, but it does look like they're starting to put more effort into it. It needs to be optimized though, I can play GTA V on max settings, but this game doesn't even have as good of graphics and even with the textures turned down and what not, it still plays like it's in slow motion. There currently aren't any brand name bikes to choose from, and none of the bikes in the game actually resemble any brand name bikes, but my face did light up when I saw that they added a graphics kit to the game that I actually have on my bike IRL. I still don't really like this game but maybe you will.

So i've played reflex for years despite all the crap that was wrong with it.  Despite all the issues and shortcommings of reflex it had one of the most fluid control systems. Supercross is a fun addition, but really not what I was expecting.

This is a step back in so many ways. I'm a KB racer. And there are many issues I've run into using the keyboard.
- All the reflex controls are not available on the KB - why can't I lean left and right?
- All the menus are designed for a controller, as the UI is all for xbox controls.
- I don't know if this is a KB issue...but the clutch...WTF? Half the time you use the clutch it blocks input until you start mashing keys.
- The camera view is really terrible in 1st person when using the KB. Unplayable.
Really enough with the awful console ports it's so frustrating!!!!!

The UI is nice, but ultimatley is designed for contollers and is also very buggy. I consistantly lose my cursor after about 3-4 races....not being able to click on things you lose your ability to use a lot of the functions in the UI

On to the actual game.
- Graphics are all locked, can't really customized.
- The scaling is terrible. Nail a triple it looks like you're jumping over a 10 story building. I thought we were past these days!
- Lots of bugs - lots of games that fail to launch, lots of spawning without a bike, glitched starts.....stuff that I thought was left in reflex.
- Preload system is a step back compared to reflex. Whips and scrubs are't fluid at all.
- Game just feels really stiff, not realy as fluid as it should feel.
- Game is too lax with full on casing jumps and running into tuffblocks.

But there is some good.
+ The game does sound awesome.
+ The clutch actually has a purpose
+ The option for manual shitfing is a nice addition
+ There are lots of gear and graphics to choose from which is nice.

In short:
This seems like another crappy console port to me right off the bat. Has some nice features, but is ultimately a step backwards and there are a lot of bugs that need to be fixed.

***update***

Supercross is a lot more playable in 1st person with a controller. Actually fun. 3rd person is complete garbage though and kills any fun to be had.

Online play seems to be a complete wliderzone at this point.

The last patch that has added Nationals has destroyed FPS. Used to run this game at 1080p 90 fps. Since the last patch FPS has droped to 50's - 30's. It's worse while broadcasting. I really don't see why this is the case as this game doesn't even look that great. Needs some serious optimization.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
+ Controls are responsive, and vehicle upgrades actually affect how your vehicle responds
+ Has free ride mode (which is most of what I do in these games)
+ AI is very balanced in difficulty, and can be very good
+ You don't have to unlock tracks in free-play
+ Can practice on any Supercross track in free-play mode
+ The different sizes of vehicles have a clearly different feel (much more difference than reflex)


Cons:
- Only one (very small) free roam map, and there is currently no modding comunity for adding more
- No cheats to unlock all bikes, so you will be grinding for a LONG time to unlock the 650's or the 50-pit bike
- No rebinding controls other than 3 premade controller layouts (although keyboard layout is quite nice)
- If you have multiple displays, the game will crash if you click outside of the game window, although alt-tabbing works fine
- Still has quite a few crashes
- haven't seen many updates since I've started playing the game
- Only looks marginally better than other MX vs ATV games, and in some cases actually looks worse.
- Menu's look much worse than Reflex (looks like they were from the PS2)
- No trucks or UTV's!

Other Notes:
The new clutch system is very odd, and can get you going much faster than you could in other games, and get you into rhythems that would have otherwise been impossible to get into, but if you don't know about it, then racing will be very hard for you as the AI almost always use it.
If there was one thing I would love the Dev's to add, it would be map support from other games in free-ride mode, or just more free-ride maps.

If you liked the Supercross modes from other MX vs ATV games, you'll like this game, because that is 90% of the game. reviewText:
Looks like after the recent update this game seems to be much better with my computer, usually getting a constant 60fps in SX and 30-45 in MX. I really do thank Rainbow for finally fixing the performane issues, so now I shall write a fair review in return. I'm gonna try and keep it short as possible, but looks like there's lots of things to cover here. I'm not trying to bash on Rainbow or Nordic in any way, just reviewing the game in my honest and opinion.

First off, the game itself is kinda fun, but doesn't really live up to what i was expecting. I was honestly hoping for a reflex2.0, but it turned out as a washed out Alive2.0.

To start here, the physics are honestly what i think are weighing down the rest of the game so much. I would have been fine if the same physics for reflex were used for supercross encore, because it really is the better of the motocross games out there. The new physics engine isn't terrible, but it feels like there was a step backwards from the right direction. The turning is like skating on brown ice simulator amped up a notch, and the whips are more like slightly maneuvering the bike sideways rather than flipping it which ever way you want like a sick pancake. scrubbing is alright but sometimes you'll end up turning sideways and transition into a super lame whip then proceed to land sideways because bringing back a whip is actually hard to do for some reason.

Braking seems to be a problem too. i had a few times when i hit the brakes and spun into a 720 noscope as if i were playing mw2 quickscope battles on rust. i know i had the oversized brakes updgrade on but jeez dude i dont think they have that kind of power.

Again, unlike reflex this game has your rider as a living tank that holds on to the bike with an absolute death grip and will only wreck if you are completely flatlining or upside down when landing a jump. Same with getting smacked into by other riders, instead of both wrecking, it just goes into bumper cars mode. and for the most part the AI is still dumb as it has been for generations now. most the time you can win a race going half speed as long as the opponents keep crashing into one another.

This game also really abuses the use of the clutch and seatbouncing, it's over powered what you can do if you just pop the clutch(which would stall the bike) and then seatbounce off a triple, you'll end up quading into the next section from the super mega ultrasanic speed boost. also it'd be real sweet if there was a manual gear shifting option, because no full sized racing dirtbike i've ever seen is automatic.


AND WHERE DID THE TRACK DEFORMATION GO?
that was one of  the coolest features for reflex, because you could carve out your out deep ruts and really rail it around berms with em, but in sx encore it seems like you cant even put an indention into the ground, sadly. Also... the rider reflex thing that you can use to save yourself from a crash is absent from this game, it's just an automatic animation. why would you do that?
so yeah it's apparent now that i really liked reflex, and lots of other mx vs atv fans can agree it's the best one out there.

Now that the biggest problem  is out of the way, i can get onto the little details and stuff i noticed were missing.

Ok, so the career mode isnt really much of a career, it's just racing after racing and getting some cool rewards, which is how it's been in pretty much all of the previous mx vs atv games. I'd like to see a career mode done differently, with sponsorships and all that fun stuff. You know another thing that's just completely missing from the supercross experience? where's all the qualifying, heats, semis, and lcq races? the race just starts off in the main event, which is really anticlimatic for me. Where's the 20 man gate drop too? i've been waiting around for that for years. This isnt much of a big deal, but it'd really add to the authenticity that makes this game supercross".

Sountrack is good for the most part with some cool fitting music

reviewText:
ALOT of people will probably disagree, but I think this game is better than Reflex. There, I said it.

There are two major things about this game that annoy me.

The first is obvious; the framerate issues. From the poor console port of Reflex from 7 years ago, until now, these games have had poor framerate issues (and graphical issues on Reflex for some cards including mine). Whenever you're by yourself on a supercross track, the framerate is almost always above 60fps on newer hardware. Anywhere else (nationals, free ride, rhythm racing), it drops considerably. The developers have said that this is due to the trees, and the lag everywhere else is due to the dirt physics and terrain deformation. I kinda halfway believe that this is the case, but whatever.

The second is the clutch kick. It is WAY too strong. Yes, it gets you out of terrible situations whenever you don't hit a rhythm perfectly, but in no way should it be that strong, especially on hard packed dirt. Once they tone that down a bit, I'd say this game is pretty spot on with its physics.

Also, the track scaling is pretty big compared to real life like it has been for previous games (except Alive, which was rebranded to this. The smaller tracks in Alive had perfect scaling IMO), but I remember seeing an interview where a developer explained that this is because they want the game to have the pick-up-and-play aspect and that the game isn't too hard. Eh, I can live with that.

If the problems can be fixed in a timely manner, this game gets a solid 8.5/10 from me. If not, it's staying at a 6/10. I can still recommend this game based on its potential and current playability.

Ok - I'm a firm believer in the early access titles.  If something doesn't feel right you can give feedback and most likely the forum of ill repute will agree with you.  I love love love love loved the last MX / ATV -- complete with the crazy trucks and tracks throught he mud and woods and craziness.  I'm not all that much for the inside tracks.  I can move the rider as I need to, the sluggishness mentioned below is because they weren't using the other stick (which controls the pitch of the rider) so you can lean into corners, lean forward in to corners, lean backward in to corners (why?! - cause you can) and it's very responsive. reviewText:
Update: Rainbow released an optimization update, the game now runs at around 60fps most of the time. It could use more but it's definately playable now.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
MX vs. ATV is back. The question is, is it good?
The answer is, kind of.

MvA Supercross Encore (long enough title?) Is an updated version of 2014's Mva Supercross originally released on Xbox 360 and PS3. The game features updated visuals, rider gear, bikes, Nationals tracks from MvA Alive, and a new event called Rhythm Racing. The game also retains the tracks from the 2014 Supercross release. The handling of the bikes was very clearly overhauled since the release of the early access version, and you can actually whip bikes around quite a bit now. Leaning into turns was drastically changed, you're able to slide around a lot more than you could before. The tracks look nice and are fun to play. Now, why is this game 'kind of' good?

The optimization is downright horrible. Really. On a GTX 680 and a Core i7, you'd think I could run this game no problem, that is NOT the case. Most tracks run at around 40-50 FPS, often dropping into the low 20s. I just can't get my head around why the optimization is so bad. Reflex had very good optimization and ran like a dream. This game, is sluggish at best, unfortunately. It really is a shame, as the new physics are actually pretty fun to play with.
Honestly, with the optimization how bad it is right now, I simply cannot reccomend this game. Yes, the tracks are fun and flow well. Yes, the new features are really nice. But the optimization is really dragging it down and I hope it gets improved within reasonable time.
